description: From Middle English substituten, from Latin substitutus, past participle of substitu≈ç.

entries.meaning: A replacement or stand-in for something that achieves a similar result or purpose.
examples: Synonyms: substituend, surrogate; see also Thesaurus:substitute

entries.meaning: (sports) A player who is available to replace another if the need arises, and who may or may not actually do so.
(historical) One who enlists for military service in the place of a conscript.

verbs.description: substitute (third-person singular simple present substitutes, present participle substituting, simple past and past participle substituted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To use in place of something else, with the same function.
examples: I had no shallots so I substituted onion.

entries.meaning: (transitive, in the phrase "substitute X for Y") To use X in place of Y.
examples: I had to substitute new parts for the old ones.

entries.meaning: (transitive, formerly proscribed, in the phrase "substitute X with/by Y") To use Y in place of X; to replace X with Y.
examples: I had to substitute old parts with the new ones.

entries.meaning: (transitive, sports) To remove (a player) from the field of play and bring on another in his place.
examples: He was playing poorly and was substituted after twenty minutes

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To serve as a replacement (for someone or something).
examples: Accumulation of wealth by this route may substitute for personal saving.
